(Photo: Eric Risberg, AP) 1 CONNECT 8 TWEET LINKEDIN COMMENT EMAIL MORE 
SAN FRANCISCO — Former Facebook Chief Financial Officer David Ebersman, who oversaw the company’s initial public offering in May 2012, faced many big decisions that month. 
But none was more important nor would have a more lasting impact on the company and its investors than what Ebersman decided the week of May 17. 
By then, Facebook’s offering was already on track to be the biggest tech IPO since the dotcom era. 
Expected to raise between $13 billion and $14 billion for the company and its early investors, the offering would dwarf the $1 billion raised by Zynga Game Network six months earlier, ​and​ the $1.​8​ billion Google raised in 2004. 
Yet Facebook’s investment bankers had drummed up so much buying interest among managers of mutual, pension and hedge funds — as well as retail stock brokers and buyers — that the IPO had the potential to be even larger. 
At the eleventh hour, ​then, ​Ebersman and the offering​'s lead bankers at Morgan Stanley decided to increase both the size and the price of the offering, raising $16 billion and valuing the social network at $104 billion. 
In the end, the decision was an obvious one for Ebersman, whose fiduciary duty was to raise as much money as possible for Facebook. 
Yet the downside of his choice to sell more than 420 million Facebook shares and saturate market demand for them became obvious the next day, May 18, when they began trading. 
Rather than enjoy an instant surge in price — what’s known on Wall Street as a first-day "pop" — the shares went nowhere, gaining just 23 cents to end the day at $38.23. More than half-a-billion shares changed hands, or more than one for every IPO share sold, showing that professional investors thought the offering was overpriced. 
Within a week, the stock had lost 18% and it kept falling until September, when CEO Mark Zuckerberg — whom the IPO had made into one of the world’s richest billionaires — promised not to sell any more shares. While the pledge from Facebook’s largest shareholder stopped the bleeding, allowing the shares to find a floor around $18, it wasn’t enough to save the stock that first year. 
One year after the offering, the shares closed at $26.25, or 31% lower than their first day’s closing price. During that same 365 days, the Nasdaq composite gained a whopping 26%. 
​When it comes to Internet IPOs that badly lag the returns of the broader market for tech stocks during their first year of trading​, Facebook has plenty of company.​ Alibaba, Twitter, Groupon and Zynga all shared that distinction, as we reported here Monday . 
Yet Facebook is alone among that group in one ​crucial​ aspect: Its shares have not only rebounded ​from their post-IPO doldrums, ​but have since soared. The shares this week have been trading between $87 and $90 a share, or more than 135% above their IPO price. 
Those who bought after the IPO froth came off the company’s valuation​, then,​ have been rewarded wi​th ​returns that have trounced the broader market. 
The Facebook IPO is a reminder of two thing. One is that, in stock buying and selling, timing is everything. It also showed that the IPO process itself sets up a zero-sum game between the listing company and its public investors. 
Every dollar more that a company raises in the offering is one dollar less left on the table for investors to profit from a subsequent rise in its share price. As with the stock option grants that give to executives and early investors millions of discounted shares, it’s a process that favors insiders over ordinary shareholders. 
Investors could have done worse than the Facebook IPO, of course. 
They could have bought IPO shares of Twitter, Zynga or Groupon, the three large Internet offerings of this investment boom that have been least kind to public shareholders. 
(We’ll look at Twitter’s IPO on Wednesday, Zynga’s on Thursday and Groupon’s on Friday.)
